captions.text:
Whoa.
Where'd you come from?

The future.
Time travel is real?

Yeah. You have no idea.
But why did you time travel back to this moment

in time? I'm just typing an email.
Cause I just saw the movie Looper with you.

You know that movie where they send people
back in time to kill people, and then Bruce

Willis and Joseph Gordon Levitt are--
Yeah, I kind of wanted to see that.

--the same person? Yeah, don't see it.
Well, why not?

Because you're going to hate it.
It's not bad. It's actually awesome. But you're

going to nitpick all the time travel logic
stuff.

Well, I do think it's interesting the movie
thinks one guy can be in one time twice and

not cause some kind of space-time continuum
issues.

Right. Exactly. That's just one of the things
you're going to find a problem with.

Like, at the end, he's trying to kill this
guy that becomes evil, but, you know, trying

to kill him is what makes him turn evil in
the first place.

That's impossible.
Yeah, I know. That's my point. You're going

to nitpick all the time travel logic--
So you've come back in time to warn me, to

stop me from seeing the movie.
Right. Right.

Doesn't that create a paradox in and of itself?
How?

You know, like, if you're successful, and
I decide not to see the movie, you can't be

here.
You'd have to disappear.

I think I'd be willing to disappear if it
means I don't have to listen to you complain

about this movie forever.
Okay. I won't see it then.

Thank you very--
He did disappear.

There's no paradox.
I'm gonna see it anyway.
Dude, what the f*ck?!

title: Conversations With Myself About Movies - Looper

comments.text:
Time travel cannot be used to change any timeline, but rather ensure a 
series of events that would lead to that timeline happening. If you were 
actually successful, you would have created two timelines, because if the 
reason of traveling back in time did not exist, you wouldn't go back. Now, 
most alternate timelines would be a nice alternative to the current one we 
have.﻿

comments.author: cortster12

comments.text:
If time paradoxes are a thing, I've always surmised that the only way to 
change anything by going into the past is for it to not be the reason you 
go back. Essentially: going back to simply observe, then changing something 
purely out of spontaneity with random chance leading the charge is the only 
way you have to make the change stick. Needless to say, this isn't exactly 
a surefire way to affect anything with any accuracy. "Let's send a bunch of 
murderous psychopaths into pre-WW2 Germany to see if they'll accidentally 
kill Hitler!"﻿

I believe that the multiverse exists, every time a molecule moves or 
changes state the timeline splits and keeps going creating a universe each 
time. So there's an infinite amount of universes all with different 
possibilities, some changes could be very vast like different values in the 
laws of physics, some would be very minor you wouldn't notice like what If 
I ate toast this morning instead of Weet-Bix? Alternate universes sounds 
far fetched and strange you might say, well isn't our own universe far 
fetched and strange? But even saying all this about multiverses there's so 
much we don't know, heck for all we know there could indeed be a creator 
whether it be a simulation on a super computer or a god like figure.﻿

comments.author: Crystal Williams-Brown

comments.text:
By that logic, there are infinite universes regarding this one comment 
reply, and 99.9999.... % are written entirely in gibberish. Like, "asdf 
asl;kjdf; a;lsdf; lajsf ;asdjf ;lkasdf;l" because those are the letters I 
would choose to type in those alternate dimension/universes. 

Also, in some universe, someone just dropped some flaming dog pooh on your 
front porch (because in a truly infinite multiverse, every iteration of 
every possible event can and does happen), better check to see if that was 
this universe or not.

It could also be assumed that in at least one of those universes, 
technology has been created to bridge or destroy universes, and for every 
person who stopped that from happening, there is an opposite universe in 
which it did happen. As such, the infinite universe theory is implausible 
by all accounts because we all still exist.

comments.author: RDF1nner

comments.text:
That is a paradox.
If you decide you won't see the movie, your future self disappears, and all 
your memories of him should too !
So you come back to your original plan : watching the movie, and so he 
should reappear !
And then the space-time continuum explodes, and then the Doctor comes and 
saves the day (and the Universe while he's there) !

Edit : That only works in a linear timeline, as Andrew Fullerton points out.
But if it's not a linear timeline, your future self shouldn't have 
disappeared. So this is definitely a paradox.﻿

comments.text:
time travel is possible but unidirectional. One can only go to the future 
not the past.Traveling faster than the speed of light causes a time warp 
but the direction is a factor. You will go forward in time only. Or seem 
to. You will be converted to a higher for of energy that resonates through 
space matter. Then due to the spherical shape of space and magnetic 
properties you will travel in an orbit around the epicenter of the 
universe. the energy released in the opposite direction during the change 
to the higher energy form will orbit in the opposite direction. It will 
meet u half phase on the opposite side of the universe without effect and 
then in full phase at the same point it was created. You will then drop in 
energy level and retain your physical form. Any matter in the area u stop 
will scatter and you will continue to decelerate. It will seem like a long 
as tail journey cuz it will be. But you would not have aged. ﻿

comments.author: Joe Schmoe

comments.text:
DBZ did it the simplest way. Which is odd considering DBZ isn't the place 
to go to find logic. They went the easy route: an infinite amount of 
parallel timelines that cannot affect one another. However, using time 
travel to go back any amount of time, or go forward any amount of time, 
except the moment you departed from, creates an alternate timeline. That's 
why Trunks, even though going back in time and stopping the Android threat, 
returned home to find absolutely nothing had changed. He had saved one 
timeline, but his own was still screwed. I've found this form of time 
travel works best and only leaves suspension of disbelief problems when 
considering how in heaven's name one can calculate a specific point in 
time, when time can be infinitesimally minute. But it's a manga, so roll 
with it.﻿

kill Cell after he awakened there. As for the Cell of the main timeline he 
was destroyed by Krillin and Trunks as they blew up Gero's secret basement 
lab.

comments.text:
And THIS is what I hate about time travel: If he comes back from the future 
to tell himself to not see the movie, and he decides not to, he makes a 
paradox. If he doesn't see the movie because he was told not to, then there 
wouldn't be someone to tell him to not see it, and since his original 
intention was to see the movie, he'll see it. If he sees it, he'll try to 
go back and tell himself to not see it, but he can't, because FUCK TIME 
TRAVEL.﻿

comments.text:
Actually, he wouldn't have disappeared. He would have never gone back in 
time to stop himself from watching the movie, which would mean that the 
conversation would have never happened, which means that you would have 
watched the movie and he would come back to warn you not to watch it. If 
you do watch it, however, you have to go back in time to warn yourself not 
to watch it because otherwise you would not have the memories of talking to 
yourself(or another version of yourself walking about) which would be a 
second paradox in, and of, itself.
Time travel, whilst physically possible, is fucked up.﻿

comments.author: Chandler Gloyd

comments.text:
Time travel must be self-consistent, meaning that whatever a time traveler 
does, it was always a part of history. Before the time traveler went into 
the past, he was visited by himself from the future, who told him what to 
say. He never had to come up with the information, so he never did.
comments.author: StormageddonDLoA42

comments.text:
It would have been created the first time it happened, and whats the 
problem with it being repeated?
comments.author: Chandler Gloyd

comments.text:
It also applies to information. If you tell your past self to say what you 
said, then your past self wouldn't have to think of what to say, and 
therefore, the information would never have been created, just repeated.
comments.author: StormageddonDLoA42

comments.text:
+StormageddonDLoA42 the bootstrap paradox assumes that the thing couldnt 
have been created in the first place.
comments.author: Chandler Gloyd

comments.text: That would be a bootstrap paradox.

comments.author: goldenspakka

comments.text:
The problem with time travel in fiction is that it's so often inconsistent. 
Old Joe attempt to prevent the Rainmaker causing his existence is a pretty 
straightforward stable time loop (the actual physics of it nonwithstanding, 
it's cropped up enough in fiction to be a standard time-travel thing), but 
then suddenly Young Joe shoots himself to kill Old Joe, and he changes the 
timeline, because he now can't fulfill the timeloop (what with being dead 
and all). Same with Back to the Future switching between 'Marty invented 
rock and roll' and 'Marty changes his family's entire living situation'. At 
least Bill and Ted were consistent.﻿

comments.author: Wallid Soukaki

comments.text:
That would only cause a paradox if you adhere to a linear timeline theory, 
which makes all time travel unlike the kind seen in Harry Potter 3 
impossible automatically.

If you believe in a divergent timeline, like Back to the Future (and unlike 
it, because Marty shouldn't have been affected by the changes in this 
parallel timeline) and Back to the Future 2 (Which shows such an obvious 
case of divergent timelines that Marty wouldn't have time traveled in the 
first place unless that was the case) it's perfectly acceptable for 
multiple versions of the same person to exist parallel.﻿
